SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Sir Frederic! and with such formality too! She hath heard of my loss then, al∣ready.—
Yet I could not have thought my Narcissa would have triumphed over my misfortune. I could not have thought she would so soon begin to upbraid and receive me coldly. Oh, woman! woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Hoity, toity! what's the matter now? The man's seriously sorrowful, as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Cruel Narcissa! what can I think of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P:
Think of it! Upon my word; I am full as much at loss what to think of it as you are. Sure the people are all at cross-purposes, or are eat up with the vapours this morning! My mama was here just now, and peevishly chid me forsooth, for being too kind to you: and now you come, in woful sadness
to complain of my cruelty! What, in the name of consistency, am I to do with you both?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: I don't wonder, Narcissa, that your ma∣ma hath changed her thoughts of me. A reverse of fortune is with fathers and mothers a sufficient motive for a reverse of sentiments. But can they, whose vows have been reciprocally exchang'd, whose hearts have been once united; can they, my Narcissa, be ever divided from motives of sordid interest? What tho' my father be dead, and, through dotard fondness has reduced his son to beggary, I have still friends, real friends, able and willing to serve me.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Your father dead! reduced to beggary! I now understand you, Sir. [Aside.] Disingenuous mama! These then were your reasons for depreciat∣ing the character of my lover! [To Frederic.] Indeed, Sir, I beg your pardon, I had heard nothing of your father's death, nor of any change in your circum∣stances: but I own the conversation I had just now with my mama, a good deal surprized me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Then she must have heard it.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: No doubt of it: and that accouuts for her behaviour.— [Aside] She may find, however, that people may sometimes be as much too reserved as too open.— [To Frederic.] But can it really be, Sir, as you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Too certainly; though I received the news myself from my father's agent but this morning, and came directly to impart it to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Was that prudent? to yourself at least? was it impossible to conceal it from me 'till after our marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P:
It was Narcissa, though no human being had known it but myself. Thoughtless and indiscreet as I am, my heart is too faithful to you, and too just to the world, to suffer me to act the part of an impostor, a single moment. Nay, I come now with a design to relinquish my pretensions, 'till the happier circum∣stances
of some future day might entitle me to aspire to the heighth from which I am fallen.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: To give up your pretensions, Mr. Mel∣moth! and was that so easy a task as to be readily resolved on?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: However rashly resolved, you have seen it was not so easy to be executed. For what have I done but solicit for that, which I came to resign?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: And you would now marry me, notwith∣standing I may have fifteen thousand pounds to my fortune, and you, as you say, not a farthing?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Narcissa!—

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Oh! you hesitate, do you?—To he sure there is some little inequality of condition in the case: but to let you see that I am more aspiring, I am ready to venture with you on the same terms.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: And is it possible you can be so good as to rate my merit above your fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Nay, don't give me time to weigh one against the other. Money is heavy, and worth is light, you know: if you take me at my word, I shall keep it: but if I am left to cool and ponderate, I won't answer for myself.—Grave faces and good advice may have a strange effect upon me. At present, I say, I'll venture with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Generous Narcissa! But whether will you venture?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Any where:—to Scotland, if you are so rash as to insist upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Spirited girl! charming Narcissa! but when?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Now, this very day, as soon as you please. My mama has dealt disingenuously by me. I will therefore beg leave of duty to stand aside a little, 'till I pay the debt I owe to love and honour. If it be a fault, I shall trust to her forgiveness this one time.— It is a fault one cannot make a practice of, you know.—So, come, let us go in, and concert proper measures for our expedition.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Charming creature! I'll accompany you to the world's end.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: O yes, I intend you shall, if we should live to the end of the world.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. Young Melmoth's Lodgings.
DIV3.P: So, so, so. I have been playing with a seeming dead coal, that hath been all the while burning my fingers. A plague of these potential cauteries, say I.—Sir John Melmoth, it seems, is really dead; my young master is a beggar, and I may carry his wallet. Sic transit gloria mundi! Had I thought the old baronet really defunct, I should not have been so pleasant with the young one's circumstances. But he is a deserving youth; and though I am horribly dis∣appointed in my own expectations, I declare I am Iess sorry for myself than for him.—What will be∣come of him!—For my own part I am qualified to struggle with the world.—Oh! here comes Sir Frederic—in a mighty good humour too! what the devil, sure his father's not come to life again!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Well, Syllogism, who hath called since. I have been out.—

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Nobody, Sir;—I expected to have been able to present your honour with at least a hundred visit∣ing cards, full of compliments of condolance: but I find the world is not so impertinent; it civily chuses to leave people under misfortunes to comfort them∣selves.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P:
It is the improved mode of good man∣ners, Syllogism, not to be troublesome. You seem, however, to stand in need of consolation! what's
the meaning of this? It is not above an hour or two ago since you braved the storns of fortune with the fortitude of a stoick, and recommended patience to me with the eloquence of a Seneca.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; but, like Seneca too, I find I cou'd preach that to others which I cannot practice myself. But surely, Sir, I may conclude, from the pleasantry of your present disposition, that what you heard in the morning cannot be true!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: True! Syllogism. How shou'd it be true, when you know you observed it to be impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Nay, but Sir, joking apart, if your father be dead, how do you intend to live, now he has dis∣inherited you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: I shall do the best: to supply my wants by industry. I shall find friends to put me in a way, and am only sorry it will be out of my power to reward your sidelity as it deserves

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, make yourself easy about me; a philosopher is easily provided for. Jacta est alea, Sir. When I have the misfortune to leave your service, I devote myself immediately to that of the muses.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: What, turn poet! then art thou con∣demned to be poor as long as thou livest. Why, the poverty of poets, man, is notorious; it hath been a hackneyed jest for ages.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, it hath been hackneyed so long, that it is fairly worn out. When poets had no patrons but the great, the poor devils, sure enough, were obliged to live upon little: but since the publick have taken them under their protection, a bard, like another man, may have two coats to his back, and every thing handsome about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: And yet, Syllogism, 'till the lawyers can decide the dispute about literary property.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P:
I grant you, Sir, that a freehold on Parnassus does not intitle the possessor to vote for member of parliament; but let a man of genius once merit the
favour of the town, and he may levy contributions on it, whenever his affairs require it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Levy contributions! is not that too ar∣bitrary? I thought the convocation of criticks had something to do in the system of literary legislation.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, they are the lower house, and have the privilege of deciding in all money-matters. They hold their sessions in the pit, at the representation of every new play, and proceed directly to the consider∣ation of ways and means.—To be sure, Sir, we can∣not raise a shilling without the consent of the house.—But if they approve the bill, they pass it with a plau∣dit, and their generosity is boundless.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Well, Syllogism, if you are obliged to go upon the town, I can only wish you success: but perhaps you may be better provided for, yet: in the mean time, you must not leave me abruptly—I shall want your service, for some time at least, I am going a journey of three hundred miles an end; will you go with me, if I should have occasion for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Te duce Teucro, to the antipodes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Come this way then, you must take a let er for me to Narcissa.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Of leave, I suppose, ah! poor girl! she'll be disappointed too! Oh! 'tis a bitter business.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV. Colonel Camply's Lodgings.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter General Melmoth and Colonel Camply.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: So then I find, colonel, you are engaged in a matrimonial expedition as well as my kinsman.— Well, I wish you success, and if you need my assist∣ance, command me.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P:
I thank you, general, and hope ere long to be able to return the compliment. Come, come,
when you have recovered your spirits a little, we shall have you looking out for a wife as well as we younger folks.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: Ah! my dear colonel!

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Ah! my dear colonel! with a sigh too! I have hit the mark then, general? What did you leave your heart in India? or hath a sudden conquest been made of it since your arrival in Europe?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: Neither, Camply. I was married many years ago, and was too unhappy in that state, ever to think of entering into it again, even if I knew myself at liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: I never heard you had been married, general.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Yes, colonel, when I went over to India, I left a wife and infant daughter in England behind me.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: And are they living?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: Alas! heaven knows! I have heard no∣thing of them for years, except from the very man, of whom being absurdly jealous, I thought I had killed.—He came over with our troops some time ago to Bengal, and convinced me by a number of corroborating circumstances, that I had injured both him and my wife; but to my sorrow, he could give me no farther information of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: How fruitless then was that!

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: Fruitless as unhappy! for though my heart was something lighter, from knowing he had recovered of the wounds I had given him; yet I shou'd have much easier supported the reflection of having killed an adulterer, than that of having in∣jured, abandoned, and perhaps ultimately destroyed, am innocent wife and daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: But why destroyed? from this relation it is not impossible they may still be living.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P:
I dare not flatter myself with such a sug∣gestion. Nay, I hardly know whether I ought to wish it true: for if she lives, must she not long since have
transferred that heart to anothet which I so unjustly suspected, so cruelly slighted?

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: But what success has attended your enquiries since?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: None; though I have made every enquiry the distance of time and place would admit.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Perhaps in your long absence, thinking you were dead, she may have married again; and thus, by her change of name, have eluded your re∣searches.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: If it be so, I will be no intruder on her happiness.—I will therefore carry on my future search in person; that, if I should succeed in it, I may be en∣abled to act as circumstances shall determine. But what a task! How dreadful is't to seek that which we hope, and yet we fear, to find! Though to be cer∣tain even of what we fear, is better far than labouring still in doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Mr. Melmoth, Sir, desires to know if your honour is alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Your kinsman, general, —Shall he come up?

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: By all means. He may have some busi∣ness with you; I'll retire into your study till you have done with him; you know I have my reasons for de∣clining to see him at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: How unlucky is this!—I must not tell Melmoth who is so near; and yet, if I don't, 'tis ten to one he'll say some extravagant thing or other; which, if over-heard, may give the general no good opinion of him. I wish my old friend were at Ben∣gal again only for one half hour, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: My dear colonel, how is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Nay, how is it with you? You seem in rap∣tures, and it is not three hours ago since I left you in a state of despondency.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Ay, you grave rogue, you—you stare to see a young fellow dejected at his ill luck in the morning, intoxicated with his good fortune before noon. But Narcissa's my own, my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Who doubted it?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: No; it wou'd have been a sacrilege to doubt it.—So that as to my father—

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Nay, but Mr. Melmoth, nothing against your father I beg of you— [Aside.] The general will certainly overhear him.—[To Melmoth.] Well, but you did not tell Narcissa of your being disinherited!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Did not I?—But I did. I told her the whole story.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: The deuce you did!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Without omitting a single circumstance.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: And—and—and— [Aside.] Egad, I believe I had better ask him no more questions—He seems in a humour to say any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: And—and—and—what a plague do you mean by your and—and—and?—Why do you look so confoundedly serious? What the devil is the matter with you?—Ah, colonel! colonel! if you did but know all!

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Nay, but I don't desire to know all— [Aside.] This spark's going to say some wild thing or other, now.

SP.SPEAKER: Y.
SP.P: Nay but you shall know all; for I came on pur∣pose to tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Well then, some other time.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: No, no other time will do: for I intend to be in Scotland by to morrow night, if possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: In Scotland!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Ay, I am going off with Narcissa to Scotland, and am come to borrow your chaise, if you'll lend it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: And what are you going to do there?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! There's a question! I thought every body knew what penny-less young fellows took girls of fortune to Scotland for.—

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Well, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Nay, nay, will you lend me your chaise? I'll tell you more of the affair by and by—I shall want a couple of your servants, too; as, for reasons of state, I shall take none of my own with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Yes, if I am to see you again—[Aside.] any thing to get rid of you now— [To Melmoth.] but I shall certainly see you again before you go.—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Certainly.—Certainly.

To Scotland! egad, Narcissa has an enterprizing spirit. If the general hath overheard nothing of our conver∣sation, I must communicate this piece of intelligence to him; it may perhaps induce him to vary his plan of operation, and save them the trouble of the journey.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: So, colonel, your young friend hath soon left you.—I thought I heard high words within.— I hope no new cause of discontent?

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Oh no, Sir; quite the reverse. Your lively kinsman is now as much elated with joy, as he was in the morning depressed with sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: How so? He can have heard nothing, sure, of the real state of his circumstances!

SP.SPEAKER: Cam.
SP.P: Nothing at all; but it seems he hath informed his mistress of his supposed loss of his father's for∣tune; and she, like a generous girl, hath agreed to give him her own instead of it.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: They are just going to set off for Scotland; he came to borrow my chaise.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: And you shall lend it them, or I will clap six horses to my own travelling coach, and that shall convey them. I like their spirit, and would encourage their expedition, were the young lady ev'n my own daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Nay, but, general, why let them take so unnecessary a step?—They will certainly be better pleased, if you should discover Mr. Melmoth's real situation, and prevent them.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Melm.
SP.P: I know not that. No, let them a while enjoy the satisfaction they feel in their mutual love and gratitude. There is more pleasure in the display of true generosity, than in the possession of mines of wealth. Let them proceed, therefore, on their jour∣ney. —I warrant it will be a pleasant one.—In the mean time, however, if it be necessary, I'll endea∣vour to reconcile the young lady's relations to the consequences of it.—But come, I called to take you home to dinner with me; we will there toast the young couple, and drink success to their spirited en∣terprize.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: So, Mr. Syllogism, you are going to have old doings at your house, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: No, no, Mrs. Sift, our old doings won't do any longer; we must have new doings now, if we intend to keep doing at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: What do you mean, Mr. Syllogism?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Nay, what do you mean, Mrs. Sift, if you come to that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Mean! why rejoicings, entertainments, to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Rejoicings! entertainments!— [Aside.]—O, the jade has heard of our misfortune I find, and has a mind to be merry with it.— [To Sift.]—You are pleased to banter, I see, Mrs. Sift.—Pray what should we rejoice at?

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Rejoice at! why, the arrival of Mr. Melmoth's father from the Indies—Have you not expected him any time these six months?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Oh, yes; and he set out from thence, it seems, near a twelve month ago; but which road he took, or whether he is arrived at his journey's end, is at present a little problematical!

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P:
Problematical! I am sure you scholars, Mr. Syllogism, are very pragmatical. Will you persuade
me I did not hear the bells ring for him this morn∣ing?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: The bells ring for him! O lud! only think of tolling the bell at Bath for a man who died at Bengal!

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Dead! Sir! What would you insinuate?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: What you know, I find, as well as I, and therefore I may venture to tell you.—My old master is dead, and hath left my young one nothing to live upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Nay, nay, Mr. Syllogism, I see you have a mind to banter me now; but come, to business. You have brought something for Narcissa, I sup∣pose.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Yes, I have got a letter for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.STAGE: —[Takes the letter, turns it about, and holds it up to the light.]
SP.P: —Why there's no reading this letter without opening it!

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: What do you think it is sealed up for, but to hinder you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Pooh! I would not give a farthing to carry such letters. Sealed! What did you never open a letter without breaking the seal? Did you never take off the impression on wax, nor coax it with a hot to∣bacco pipe?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: No, Mrs. Sift, they are arts I have not been bred to.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Well, I have done it an hundred times, who was never bred to the arts at all: though I remem∣ber I once lost the best place I ever had in my life, for breaking open a letter, and sealing it up again with my thimble.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: And deservedly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Yes, I paid for my peeping that time, it's true; but I should have done it, had I been to die for it. I am astonished to think how any body can have so little curiosity, as not to long to know every thing that other people want to keep from them.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: I would as soon put my hand into my master's purse, as pry into his secrets; and think a servant deserves to be hanged as much for the one as the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: That is, if it be done with intent to betray them, Mr. Syllogism; but otherwise—and yet, to be sure, one does sometimes do a deal of mischief by getting into secrets by halves; but that is the fault of one's masters and mistresses, you know, in not trusting us with the whole.—You will not pretend to tell me, however, that you have no curiosity to know your master's business.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Faith I have no curiosity to know more than he thinks proper to intrust me with. I have plague and trouble enough with that; if I knew less, I should live a much easier life: for what between his money-matters and those of his mistress, which you know, Sift, are both ticklish affairs, I have but a very troublesome time on't.
SP.STAGE: [While Syllogism is speaking, Sift is looking at the letter, and turning it about in her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: There must be something very curious, Syl∣logism, in this letter. It is doubled into so many pleats, and folded up as carefully as the Welch-man's guinea—there is certainly something choice in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Ay, all love I suppose, Sift.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Love! eh!—that's choice stuff, to be sure! —Well, I see the direction.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: And you'll deliver it safely—you understand me—you need not be at the trouble of quartering my master's coat of arms with the milliner's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: O! the thimble! no, upon my honour.—

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: You see the crest is a lion rampant, beware of the top of your middle finger.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Nay, but when I say upon my honour, Mr. Syllogism.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P:
I beg your honour's pardon, Madam. To be sure, after having so frankly confessed its influ∣ence over your curiosity in these cases, it wou'd be
cruel to distrust you — [Aside as he goes out.] If I had my letter again however, I would as soon leave it with the printer of the Public Advertiser.

They think they are mighty close here—It is writ∣ten with lemon juice, surely!—Well I have a trick for that; my mistress shan't set me upon the enquiry for nothing I am too good a servant for that too— Ha! our young ladies coming this way!—I am deter∣mined to have another peep at it, be the consequence what it will. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Well, really Sophia, this is something ex∣traordinary that you shou'd affect to tutor me, for disobedience to my mama, in the preference I give to Mr. Melmoth: hath not she, 'till this very day, al∣ways approved of his addresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Therefore I am afraid, Narcissa, she has some better reasons for her sudden change of behaviour than you are aware of: at least I shou'd be for com∣ing to a farther explanation with her before I took so irretrievable a step as you are going inconsiderately to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Oh! my dear, we shall take a great many steps before we get to Scotland. We shall not be across the Tweed so soon as we might be at the next parish church. I shall have time to consider of it again and again, therefore, before the business is done yet.—Nay, I can assure you that even when we get there, if I shou'd not happen to be perfectly of the opinion I am in at present, we may come back again no wiser than we set out. If the matrimonial appa∣ratus does not wear a very agreeable aspect—if Mess-John does not put on one of his best faces, and his cleanest band;—or—

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Nay, but be serious.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Well, I am: and say as I did before, that if there were really any thing wrong in what I am going to do, you shou'd be the last person in the world, my dear Sophy, to dissuade me from it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sopht
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Because I should never listen to a lecture on disobedience from one as disobedient as myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: How! cannot I entertain a proper regard for colonel Camply, without incurring the guilt of dis∣obedience? I don't intend to run away with him, or even to marry him, without my father's consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc
SP.P: Not unless he refuses to give it you; there is no occasion for't, my dear. But if by a proper re∣gard, you mean that the colonel is in possession of your heart, I warrant your hand will soon follow. And, tho' you may want courage to scamper away to the North, before you come of age, you may only have just patience enough to stay in the South 'till you do; when we shall find you sneaking into the back-door of Walbrook-church, or St. Swithins, to commit the like horrid sin of disobedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: I find, my dear, there is no talking to you on this subject: so, like a naughty girl, you must go on your own way.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: And you, like a naughty girl, Sophy, wou'd go my way too, if you dar'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: The devil take the inventors of sealing-wax, and invisible ink;—I can pick nothing out of this letter— so I think may as well give it to my young mistress. If she can read it, I may possibly pick something of it out of her, and that will do as well.—A letter for you, Madam

SP.SPEAKER: Narc
SP.P: From Mr. Melmoth!

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Yes, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: You will excuse me, Sophy, I must go and read my billet-doux; it may possibly require an an∣swer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: So!—now for a peep over the left shoulder.—Let the writing be but any how visible, and if young madam reads any more of it than I, why then, I am grown short∣sighted—that's all.

Was ever any thing so determinedly inconsiderate? —and yet Narcissa does not want for prudence, when the vivacity of her temper will suffer her to make use of it.—I wish I cou'd any how prevent this rash expedi∣tion, without betraying the confidence she has placed in me. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Urge this affair no farther, Furnival. I can be of no service to you in it.—I have consulted my heart, and find it repugnant to all my sentiments. The love I bear Narcissa, and the regard due to my own honour; both forbid it.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: Give me leave to say, my lord, your scruples are too refined for a man so well acquainted with the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Yes, barrister, I know the world too well to sacrifice so much of my own happiness, either to its pleasures or opinions, as I have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: But if your lordship has no hopes of Narcissa, what objection can be made to your repairing your fortune by marrying another? Surely, my lord, nei∣ther the laws of love or honour forbid this!

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P:
Perhaps not— but I feel an invincible re∣luctance to the making my addresses elsewhere. It is
true; Narcissa herself gives me no encouragement; but her mother is still my friend, and affords me hopes that something may turn out in my favour: I have even just now received a message from her, desir∣ing to see me in the evening, on particular business.— Who knows what may have happened? But be it as it may, I cannot resolve to devote myself to another, 'till it be impossible for Narcissa to be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: And your lordship is determined to decline the obliging offers of Mr. alderman Lombard, with regard to the money matters I was speaking of?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: If they are made on a presumption that I shall serve him where I have neither the power nor incli∣nation.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: I am heartily sorry for it, my lord; as this is not the way to pay off the mortgage on your estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Then it must remain unpaid, barrister, 'till a more honourable method offers for its discharge.

His lordship is in one of his moral moods to day. —I must resume the subject at a gayer moment.— And yet I'm half afraid he's lost.—These partial attachments to the sex are the ruin of many a noble spirit. While he was only a general lover, he was the most enterprizing genius on the turf.—But now—'Tis strange; but we sometimes find it in the power of one virtuous woman to reform in a few months what the libertine part of both sexes have been labouring to corrupt for years.—These modest wenches make as many converts as the me∣thodist parsons—Whom have we here?—the very ladies in question, as I live!—and engaged in earnest discourse!—It may be worth listening to— I have an excellent knack of hearing at a distance. [Retires.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: And you are really determined, Narcissa, to put this wild scheme in execution.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Positively, my dear Sophia.—I shall not break my word with Mr. Melmoth, if he keep his with me. We are to have your colonel's chaise wait∣ing for us at the town's end. I shall just go to the rooms with you for form's sake, and see you set in for cards, and then vanish; slip into a chair, and be with my spark in a twinkling: leaving you, my dear, or your colonel, to make the best apology you can for me to my mama.—I have left a short one indeed myself in a letter she will find on her return in the evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: As you have made me your confident, my dear, I shall not betray you. But I cannot say I ap∣prove of this step. Indeed I really think it unneces∣sary. I am certain your mama might be brought to give her consent to your marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Nay then there is the less harm, my dear, in going to be married without it. If she has no ob∣jections, you know, but what might be removed by solicitation, the solicitation would be merely a matter of form, a piece of childish ceremony.—Besides, my dear Sophy, to answer all your petty scruples about disobedience at once, I am determined on the thing precisely, because I would not be disobe∣dient.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Ay; make that out, Narcissa.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P:
Very plainly.—My mama has not yet positively told me she would not have me marry Mr. Melmoth:—on the contrary, she has hitherto encouraged his addresses: but as I shrewdly suspect she might tell me so in plain terms the next time we converse on the subject, I don't intend to give her an opportunity of laying me under any such injunction. —Because, in that case, you know, it would be
downright disobedience to act directly against her positive commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Well; for such a mad-cap, thou art cer∣tainly a very extraordinary casuist.—So joy go with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: I warrant it will. I only wish we may bring it back again; and make it last as long as the wed∣ding ring and the parson's benizon hold us together. —So come along.

So, so, so—Here's an affair broke out!— What will his scrupulous lordship say to this?— Egad, we just nicked the time. The bird is feather∣ed, and just on the wing. But the lime and twigs shall be ready, my dear. No, no, my pretty flut∣terer, you must not take flight, and leave us yet, neither.—What if I worked by stratagem, and en∣trapped my little lapwing in her own snare!— Her chairmen may possibly be prevailed on to mistake the place of rendezvous.—If I can but decoy her to his lordship's apartments, he may set her at liberty himself, if he chuses it. It is a pretty Canary-bird, and would become a gilt cage mightily.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. Mrs. Mildmay's Lodgings.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Mildmay, (with an open letter in her hand) followed by Sift and Susan.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: To Scotland! and with young Mel∣moth—rash, unadvised girl!—Dispatch somebody to colonel Camply. Tell him I must speak with him instantly, on business of the utmost censequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Susan.
SP.P: Yes, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Oh! Narcissa!

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: But why, Madam, should you make yourself so very uneasy? Mr. Melmoth is a worthy young gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Talk not to me of his worth—

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: And the young people, heaven bless them! were passionately fond of one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs.
SP.P: Mild. Ah! too passionately—

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Then Mr. Melmoth is—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: You know not what he is, Sift: nor can I tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My lord Courtly, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Shew him up.

DIV3.P: See that colonel Camply be found immediately, Sift. [Exit Sift.
Oh! my lord, I am the most terrified and distressed of women. The delight of my heart, the wish of yours, my darling Narcissa—

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Narcissa! what of Narcissa, Madam? you alarm me beyond expression. Surely no accident—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Yes. the most dreadful accident!— in the most sudden and unexpected manner is she gone off with young Melmoth for Scotland.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Then are my hopes at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Not so, my lord, if their design be prevented. They cannot be got far as yet. Your lordship will assist me in immediately pursuing them.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P:
If my preventing Narcissa's marriage with Mr. Melmoth, might induce her to bestow her heart on me, Madam, you might command me: but I fear hearts are not to be transferred, and she has now
given a sufficient proof on whom she has freely be∣stowed hers. I cannot therefore think of robbing another of what he has so good a right to possess, because I had not the merit of a successful rival.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Alas, my lord, Mr. Melmoth can be no rival.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: You flattered me indeed, Madam, with the discovery of a circumstance in my favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Mild.
SP.P: It is this very circumstance, my lord, that aggravates my present distresses; as I now fear, that, instead of contributing to your happiness, it will only tend to my misery.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What is it then, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: In the present situation of things, my lord, I cannot refuse to impart it to you; though I have reason for concealing it a while from all the world besides.—Mr. Melmoth is—Narcissa's bro∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Narcissa's brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: By the most providential means, I this day discovered it; therefore, my lord—

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Nay, Madam, if that be the case;—but are you certain I

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Most certain;—therefore make no delay. Narcissa cannot be Mr. Melmoth's; she may be yours, and be happy.—All depends on the moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Then depend on't, Madam, I will give you a good account of my time. Your servants will assist me to procure the means of pursuit, and be assured you shall speedily hear from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: One thing more, my lord. If either persuasion or force may effect their return, let the circumstance of their affinity be as yet kept a secret from them.— I have particular reasons for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I shall obey your commands, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P:
Who waits there? John! Thomas! attend upon his lordship.—Well, now I am some∣thing easier. The inconsiderate sugitives will be
overtaken. Inconsiderate indeed! but alas, had it been otherwise, how innocent had been their crime! Yet happy is it, that, through all the various acci∣dents of life, there is an over-ruling providence, which often preserves us from the ill consequences even of our own indiscretions.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV. A Street near Lord Courtly's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Furnival, disguised in a Cloak, followed by a chair, with the curtains drawn.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: This way, Patrick.— [In a low voice, and exit.1st Chairm. Which way your honour pleases. 2d Chairm. Ay, I thought young madam would not be after going out of town to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: What a round-about way have these fel∣lows taken! but I was only bid to follow them, and and so, ite, pre, sequar.— [Going off, stops short.]— Hey day! they turn into a house!—Sure that is more than we bargained for.—I hope there is no mistake here.—Drinking to besure depresses the judgment, though it elevates the imagination: if potation, however, deprives a man of his discretion, it gives him courage to face the peril it leads him into. Not that I am so tipsy as to be very valiant neither, though I did get rather a cup too much in waiting, ere the dog-trotting scoundrels were put in motion.—But I have classical authority for taking a chearful glass in the evening, Ut vites poenam de polibus incipe caenam.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Syllogism! What are you doing here? Where is Narcissa? Did not I bid you watch her coming out of the rooms, and follow her chair?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: You did, Sir, and so I have. It is just gone into that house.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Into a house! you must have mistaken some other chair for her's. What a blockhead! why you're half drunk;—you can't see.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: No, no, Sir, it is no deception; as sure as you stand there, I saw the chair, that brought Nar∣cissa from the rooms, go into that house.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Melm.
SP.P: Is't possible! For heaven's sake who lives there?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Why, Sir, that I was posing myself about, when you came in.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: As I live, lord Courtly's old lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, and now I recollect, I believe his new ones too. I think I saw some of his servants about the door to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Was she brought hither by her own di∣rection?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Faith, Sir, I can't tell; but it certainly must be with her own consent, or otherwise she would have prevented it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: And why did not you?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, you know my orders were only to see the chair safe where it was carried to, and there to leave it. So, Sir, I walked a chalk after it, as still as a mouse all the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: But you knew whither it was going, why did not you make the fellows keep strait for∣ward.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir, I found it a little dif∣ficult to keep quite strait forward myself. Besides, Sir, I thought these fellows must know their way about the town better than I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: What can be the meaning of this? Sure Narcissa does not intend to jilt me! to give her hand to lord Courtly after all! O no! that is impossible.

DIV3.STAGE: [Goes out at the side of the scene, looking up at the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Impossible! ah, Sir! so you said, you know, when you heard of your father's death; but, under correction, Sir, it is just as possible for a young lady to give away her heart, as for an old gentleman to give up the ghost.—Inconstancy and intemperance are both fatal in their consequences;— [Hicups]—But then those consequences are so very common, that there are matches broke off, and funerals performed to every part of England daily; and for that matter, Sir, under correction—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Ha! the door opens! stand back, Syllogism, somebody is coming.

DIV3.STAGE: [They retire to the back of the scenes.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: —I insist upon going, Sir; let go my hand, Sir; What is the mean∣ing of this insolence?

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: You must not risk the danger, Madam, of going at this time of night alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: I can be no where in so much danger as in staying with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: Nay, but Mr. Melmoth will be here imme∣diately, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: He is here already, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Oh! Mr. Melmoth what a villainous trick has been play'd us?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, how came this lady here? and to what purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: You shou'd ask the one of the chairmen who brought her, Sir; and the other of the lady who doubtless directed them.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P:
Come, Sir, no shuffling. How came you to mention my name, as a pretence for detaining
her?—Expect to be called to a severe account for this piece of treachery.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: Faith, Sir, my design was merely to oblige my friend lord Courtly, in preventing the lady's elopement.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: And what right had either you or he, Sir, to pry into, or controul her actions?

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, I shall not enter into the matter of right, as the lady has nothing to complain of, but being prevented committing an act of disobedience.— But, yonder I see comes my lord himself with the ser∣vants of the family, to conduct the young lady home.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Confusion! how cou'd we be thus be∣tray'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Betray'd indeed! and by what infamous means! I did not think my lord Courtly cou'd have descended to such baseness, or my mama have abet∣ted it. But they shall reap no advantage from the suc∣cess of it.—Lead the way, Mr. Melmoth, and I'll follow you through all opposition.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Syllogism, stand to your arms.—

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, and I'll make any body else stand too, or fall, that offers to molest you.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Ha; Narcissa! and Mr. Melmoth! fortu∣nate encounter.— [To the servants.] Stand back till you are called for.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Perhaps not so fortunate as you imagine, my lord.—

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: For you I am sure it is: and as for myself, the service I may do you both, will at least entitle me to your gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: If you are serious, my lord, your absurdity borders on impertinence; if you mean to be ironical you are extremely ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I flatter myself, Madam, you will soon think otherwise; and that however unsuccessful I have hitherto been, I shall, for my assiduity to night, be rewarded with your good opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Indeed, my lord, you are egregiously mistak∣en. What extravagance! To employ your base para∣site to decoy me to your house, and flatter yourself to obtain my good opinion of it. Indeed, indeed, my lord, this is one of the grossest instances of self-adula∣tion I ever met with.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Decoy you to my house, Madam! I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: Indeed, Madam!— [To Narcissa.] I can an∣swer for his lordship's innocence in that particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Yes, yes, we shall certainly take your word for his innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Be prepared, Sir, to answer for your own —But come, Narcissa, — [offering to go] we lose time.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Let me intreat you not to be too precipitate. Mrs. Mildmay entreats, nay insists that you will proceed no farther without consulting your friends.—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: One of which, I presume, is to be your lordship. No, no, my lord, we have lost too much time by your contrivance already.—Therefore stand aside, if you please.—

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Nay, but for your own sakes.—

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: For our own sakes, my lord, or yours! Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: This is no place to enforce my own preten∣ions: I act now only in obedience to Mrs. Mildmay; who charged me, to say, that all laws human and di∣vine, oppose your union.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: Very pathetic indeed, my lord! Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: I must second this motion.— [to young Melmoth.] Yes, Sir, and as the lady is a minor, the laws of England too—

SP.SPEAKER: Y.Melm.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, we shall not venture to break the laws of England, 'till we get into Scotland: so that you may spare your rhetorick.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: On my honour, Madam, you cannot be the wife of Mr. Melmoth.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: But I suppose I might be your's, my lord, if I aspired to that dignity; and so in return for your extraordinary friendship I promise you, that when I find I cannot be Mr. Melmoth's, I will give my hand to your lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: If I should take you at your word, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: I will certainly keep it, and so now, I hope, you are satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: But Narcissa!

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Your humble servant, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Mr. Melmoth!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Melm.
SP.P: My lord, your most obedient.—Come Narcissa, we'll take this way—poor lord Courtly! Ha, ha, ha! [Exit young Melmoth and Narcissa.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Madness and folly! How rash and resolute! At all hazard they must be prevented. Mrs. Mild∣may must unfold the secret.—Advance there—Bar∣rister, pursue and detain them till I return with the lady's mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: Follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Hold, hold, Mr. Barrister, not a step farther, if you please—and you, gentle∣men, keep back I charge you, as you set a store by your respective pericraniums.— [Brandishing his endgel, the sevents make a shew of resisting with their sticks.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: What does the fellow mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: I'll shew you that, Mr. Lawyer. [Throwing open his great coat, and shewing a blunderbuss slung over his shoulders.] Do you see this curious piece of ca∣suistry? it contains very weighty reasons against you I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: A blunderbuss loaded with slugs, I suppose a powerful way of arguing indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: This, Sir, is the ultima ratio dialectici, and and is the most effectual argumentum ad hominem in the whole system of logic.

DIV3.STAGE: [Presents the piece to the servants, who start back.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: Is the man mad, or drunk?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Be which he will, Sir, we had better retire, for fear of mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, you had better take good advice, and retire, for fear of mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: Wou'd the wretch commit murder?

SP.SPEAKER: Syllog.
SP.P: Not downright murdrum, Mr. Barrister, as you wou'd call it; but being a little inebriated, one's hand is liable to shake, and this damned trigger here has no catch. [Plays with the lock of the piece, with the mouth turned towards Furnival.] Besides, Sir, I am placed here upon duty; and by all the rules of war and logic, if you proceed vi et armis, I must oppose you by the same mode of ratiocination; there∣fore give up the point, ye scoundrels, [Turning round, and presenting the piece at the servants] or I will let fly such a shower of majors and minors among you, that shall make you tremble for the consequences.

SP.SPEAKER: Furn.
SP.P: What, all gone! then I think I may as well withdraw my plea too. His lordship will certainly be nonsuited. [Sneaks off.

So! the enemy hath made his retreat, and the day's my own. Egad I think I have displayed my prowiss pretty well here.—I hope by this time my general hath carried off the spoils of the field, and then I shall have nothing to do but make an end of my supper, and sing Te deum for the victory— with a health to the King.—Tol de rol, tol de rol.—

DIV3.STAGE: [Shoulders his blunderbuss and struts off, singing the tune of the Belleisle march.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE the Parade.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter general Melmoth and colonel Camply.

SP.SPEAKER: General Melmoth.
SP.P: THAT was unlucky, colonel—and so the young folks were intercepted in their flight.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Camp.
SP.P: By the lady's mother, Sir; who, being early informed of their intention, was by the aid and advice of lord Courtly at the place of rendezvous be∣fore they set off. For my own part, apprehensive that my assistance would be called for, I purposely kept out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: And how takes my kinsman his rival's in∣terposition in this affair? Have you seen him to day?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Cam.
SP.P: Just now; and horribly mortified at his disappointment, I assure you. He had just dispatch'd a note to lord Courtly.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: A challenge! ha! colonel!—a mettled spark! But we must have no fighting, if it can be de∣cently prevented: the consequences may be fatal.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Cam.
SP.P: I don't see how Mr. Melmoth can recede, general; he must call his lordship to account for his last night's misbehaviour.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P:
Well, but you may be his second, colonel, and prolong the ceremonials 'till I have had some talk with the young lady's mother. I promised yes∣terday to endeavour to conciliate matters with her re∣lations, had she gone off with my kinsman to Scot∣land;
I can do no less than try how far my influence may extend now. If Mrs. Mildmay's objections to young Melmoth be merely founded on his supposed want of fortune, they are readily obviated; and if lord Courtly be as you say, a man of sense and principle, he will give up the point; and no longer endeavour to divide two young people, whose hearts seem form'd for each other. O! here comes Mr. Alderman Lombard.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: I had a meeting with him last night, to settle the affair of my executorship; when I took an opportunity to mention yours with his daughter, Sophia; as also your electioneering business; in which he does not meet with the encouragement he expected; so that you may not find him so refractory as you imagined.—I have taken some steps towards your reconciliation.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Cam.
SP.P: This is so kind and obliging in you, ge∣neral—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Nay, no compliments, my dear colonel; while dead to family connexions myself, I live but for the service of my friends. Enter alderman Lombard. Good-morrow, Mr. Alderman.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: Good-morrow to you, general.—(to Camply) your humble servant, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Colonel Camply, Mr. Lombard, a gentle∣man extremely desirous of a more intimate acquaint∣ance with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: I know it, Sir.—Tho' a stranger to his per∣son, I am none to his name, and pretensions.—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: To both which, Sir, I hope you will soon be reconciled.

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: I don't know that, Sir.—You set up for a borough, it seems, that I want to get for myself.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Cam.
SP.P: I do, Sir, at the general request of the con∣stituents.

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: And you put up for a daughter too, whom perhaps I have a mind to keep to myself.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: What, if you can dispose of her to advan∣tage, and make her happy in a good husband, Mr. Lombard! No, no. I dare say you are too good a father for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, general, if I could promote her happiness, and my influence in the borough at the same time—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Both which I dare say you will, in concilia∣ting matters with my friend, the colonel. You own, Mr. Lombard, the force of the arguments I made use of last night.—I shall now, therefore, leave the discus∣sion of the matter to yourselves; having some busi∣ness of consequence to dispatch elsewhere. Mr. Lom∣bard, your most obedient.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: General, your servant.—Well, young gentle∣man, what is it you have to propose?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Cam.
SP.P: Sir, if you please to step to my lodging, we may there talk the matter over a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: Look'ye, Sir, if you love my daughter, you must give up the borough.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Cam.
SP.P: Sir, I have the highest regard for both, and doubt not I shall be able to satisfy you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: I am not so soon satisfied, Sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: C. Cam.
SP.P: This way, Sir, if you please.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lom.
SP.P: My daughter or the borough, Sir, —take your choice—Sophy or Gluttonbury—mind, I stick to that.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. Mrs. Mildmay's.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Well, Sift, and can you learn whether the story Mr. Melmoth hath told Narcissa be true.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: O lord, Madam, it is exactly as I guess'd yesterday. What Mr. Melmoth told Narcissa, Mr. Syllogism told me; but I knew it was a sib the mo∣ment I heard it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: But how are you assur'd of it to∣day!

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: From colonel Camply's own mouth, madam; who call'd me into the parlour this morning, and be∣gan to catechise me like a school-master. Mrs. Sift, says he, what makes you abroad so early? What, your ladies have sent you out upon the enquiry, I suppose, I know they are curious and inquisitive.—Indeed, Sir, says I, you know no lady in our house half so inquisi∣tive as myself. Well, says he, what's the news then, at home? Why, Sir, says I, we hear that Mr. Mel∣moth's father is dead, and has disinherited him.— Disinherited him! says he, an idle story, Sift, an idle story, there is nothing in it.—So I thought, an please your honour, said I, for I understood Mr. Melmoth was son to the strange gentleman who visited you yesterday. Ay, Sift, says he, while that gentleman lives, Mr. Melmoth's fortunes are in the hands of a father.—Oh, ma'am, I'm positively certain it is as I first suggested.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Then so far all is well; but did you learn nothing more?

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Oh, yes, ma'am; you wanted to know if the gentleman was married or not: but that seems to be a doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: A doubt! Did colonel Camply say it was a doubt!

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: No; madam, I did not think that a proper question to put to the colonel. But Mrs. Tiptoe, his honour's house-keeper, with whom I had a little confab afterwards, over-heard the gentleman tell her master yesterday that he was married.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: How then is it a doubt?— [aside] Oh no! my fears are true, and I must still be wretched.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Why, it seems, madam, the gentleman has lost his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Lost her! How?

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: Nay, ma'am, I know nothing more than that he can't find her; so that at least she is lost to him. He has not seen her, I find, these twelve years past though, by his own account, which is a little extra∣ordinary, he has been looking for her almost from one end of the world to the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Good heavens! my hopes revive.

SP.SPEAKER: Sift.
SP.P: The colonel, advises him, if he don't find her soon, to look out for another: but he is one of your constant swains it seems; and declares, that if his first love cannot be found, she shall certainly be his last.— Whether the gentleman will keep his word or not, is another affair. But this is all I could learn of the matter, madam, as it stands at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: I am satisfied. [aside.] Is he then true to one he thought unfaithful? and can he still remem∣ber me with tenderness? [to Sift.] Go, leave me, Sift; I see Narcissa coming.—

DIV3.P: Well, Narcissa, I hope, that, on reflection, you are convinc'd of the danger and impropriety of your be∣haviour. Think, my dear, into what frightful perils your indiscretion had betray'd you. Believe me, child, such unadvis'd proceeding, differs little from wilful disobedience.—

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Indeed, madam, I shudder at the reflection, and am hardly recover'd from the terrour into which your relation had thrown me.—But, with regard to Mr. Melmoth's affinity, how was it possible for me, to have any suspicion of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: It certainly was not: but, in a matter of so much importance, you should not have acted so precipitately.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Nor should I, mama, had not you been so much on the reserve, and spoken of Mr. Melmoth so disrespectfully yesterday morning.—But, for the fu∣ture, I am all obedience.—How would you have me behave to him now?—as you said so little to him last night, he will undoubtedly make me a visit this morn∣ing. —How am I to resist his solicitations, without giving him my reasons for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Cannot you turn the conversation on another subject? I shall now very soon come to an ex∣planation with your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: My father! madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Yes, Narcissa, that long-lost father, whom you have heard me so often lament, is now in Bath. I saw him yesterday by accident, and to-day in∣tend to procure an interview; which should have been over, before I had imparted this circumstance, had not your last night's adventure anticipated the dis∣covery of Mr. Melmoth's being your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: But, is it not strange, madam, that he should say nothing to me of his father's arrival? But, on the contrary, should tell me he was dead, and had disin∣herited him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: I cannot divine his reasons for such be∣haviour. But, men in love, Narcissa, are strange creatures. He might do it, possibly, to make a trial of your regard for him.—

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: It must have been a scheme sure to mislead me into that dangerous project of elopement, which might have prov'd so fatal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: It might be so; and therefore it would not be amiss, my dear, if you affect to resent it as such; nay, I would have yon do it, were it only to give a preparatory check to his passion, before he knows that you're his sister. It will be improper for me to see him yet, as well in regard to what has pass'd, as to the danger of betraying a mother's affection too soon. I must speak first with your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: In what a situation then, madam, do you leave your Narcissa? Is it for me to act so hard a part? Can I affect to treat with disregard, the man so late I lov'd? Alas! I find his image wanting here. The. void it left, no brother can supply.—Oh! my poor heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: I share, my dear Narcissa, your distress; and would not task you with a mother's weakness, But, for this once, call up your resolution: an expla∣nation yet were premature.—But here he comes—I must retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Then let my duty teach me to dissemble.

DIV3.STAGE: (As he enters) Narcissa! and alone! I feared this hap∣piness had been denied me.—My dear, Narcissa! I am glad to see you look so charmingly to-day.—I was afraid, the ill success of our last night's adventure, might have had an effect upon your spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.STAGE: [In a trembling voice, being greatly disturbed.]
SP.P: Not at all, Sir, I never was in better spirit in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Indeed! I wish I could say so—but our unlucky disappointment!

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Unlucky!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Cruelly so: we might, ere this, have been half-way on our journey; and, in a few hours more, at the end of it;—where we might have put it out of the power of accident to part us.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: For that very reason, Mr. Melmoth, may it not be as well we were prevented?—What! to be tied together for life! never to be parted! Might we not, in time, have been tir'd of one another; and, after that, have been most disagreeable companions?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Glad we were prevented! tir'd of one ano∣ther! disagreeable companions! How different is this language, and this behaviour, Narcissa, to that of yesterday?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: What if I should have chang'd my mind since yesterday, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Chang'd your mind, Narcissa!

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Is it impossible, Sir?—Did you never hear of a woman's changing her mind?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Yes, madam, I have heard of wonderful changes in women's minds:—but you are not in ear∣nest, Narcissa?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I am at present in no disposition for jesting.—
SP.STAGE: [Very gravely and confused, as through the whole scene.]

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: And you are really glad we were prevented going to Scotland to be married? Surely you dissem∣ble with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Not in that, believe me, Sir.—I would not have gone off with you to Scotland, and been married to you, for the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Nay, then there is a change indeed.—But, for heaven's sake, why? What can have work'd this astonishing alteration? What have I done, or said, or thought? How am I chang'd, that such a change should have happened in you? Some villain, envious of my happiness, must have unjustly traduc'd, and blacken'd my reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P:
Why, something has been said of you, it must be confess'd. But it was so far from be∣ing to your disadvantage, that, had I never had any knowledge of you before, it would have induc'd me to love and esteem you as a brother.—But, with re∣gard to your own behaviour to me, Mr. Melmoth, I
must own it has been very exceptionable. How could you tell me, Sir, that your father was dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: He is, Narcissa.—

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Fie, fie, Mr. Melmoth.—I am well assur'd your father is still living; and, must freely declare, that were there not another man in the world, I would not give my hand to his son.— [aside, bursting into tears.] —Now, I hope, my mama will be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Do I live? Am I awake?— [looking after her with astonishment.]—Was that Narcissa? or am I Frederic Melmoth? What can be the meaning of all this?—If she be lost, I know at least who to thank for it.—Lord Courtly shall pay dear for this officiousness. —I must and will have this behaviour explained.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. Another apartment in the same house.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter General Melmoth, shewn in by a servant,

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Please to walk this way, Sir.—Mrs. Mild∣may desires to be at present excus'd; but my young mistress will wait on you immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Madam, your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: —Another painful task! Is this my father? certainly it is—he strikes me with an awe I never felt before.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: I am sorry, madam, I cannot have the pleasure of seeing Mrs. Mildmay.

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.STAGE: [Hesitating and confused, as thro' the whole of this scen▪
SP.P: You have then business with my mama, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: I have, madam; but, as you are princi∣pally concerned in it, I shall, with your leave, impart it to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: If it be of immediate consequencc, Sir— otherwise I should rather—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Nay, but young lady, it is of consequence, and to you too: I am not to learn, with regard to your late generous behaviour to Mr. Melmoth.—I am a relation of his; and, apprehending your last night's disappointment might have some disagreeable con∣sequences, which I am able to remove, I have taken the liberty of the present intrusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: This openness of behaviour on your part, Sir, would be a reproach to any mean reserve on mine. But I am only at liberty to say, that the dis∣appointment, as you call it, was a fortunate one.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Is it possible you can think so? Then must I have been misinform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: You will excuse me, Sir; but my mama hath fully convinc'd me, that my intended marriage with Mr. Melmoth, would have been highly improper.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Improper!

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Dreadful!—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: You astonish me, madam.—Dreadful! What new folly hath he committed, then? to what baseness descended, that should make an alliance with him deserving such an epithet?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Don't mistake me, Sir;—I have still the highest esteem for Mr. Melmoth; but my mama—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Objects to his want of fortune; I know it. But if I convince her she is mistaken.—

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Yet even then, Sir, notwithstanding the sincere regard I still entertain for Mr. Melmoth, and the great respect which, though a stranger, I feel for yon, I could not be induc'd to listen to the solicitations of either.—No, Sir, I never can marry any man who calls you father.—But I can explain myself no far∣ther. My mama is, by this time, disengag'd, and will herself attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P:
What is all this? Respect for me!—not marry any man who calls me father!—I am not young
Melmoth's father; and if I were, what then?—unless —but here comes the mother; she may speak more plainly.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Mildmay. [Who stands at a distance, and looks at him with tenderness.]
DIV3.P: I beg pardon, madam, but— [bowing ceremoniously, and advancing, 'till looking full in her face, he retreats slowly back.] Sure—that face—I—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Mr. Wildman!

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Her voice too!—Gracious powers!—It is —'tis she—it is—it is—my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Yes; I am your wife, your once be∣loved wife.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: And still belov'd!—Come to my arms, thou long-lost, injur'd woman.— [they meet and em∣brace.] Oh, my wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: And art thou still my husband?—I thought thou hadst forgotten me.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Forgotten thee! Oh, never, never.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mid.
SP.P: Hast thou forgiven me too?—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Forgiven thee, love!—Why, thou didst never wrong me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Indeed, I did not; even when you thought me guilty, I was innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: I know thou wast; and 'tis in knowing that, that I've so long been wretched.—Yes, thou wast in∣nocent; but it was I, 'twas I, forgot the father and the husband, and wrong'd both thee and thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Yet, I was indiscreet, and much to blame.

SP.SPEAKER: G. M.
SP.P: Idle recrimination! no; you never were to blame—and yet, your name is Mildmay.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P:
Nay, turn not from me—I perceive your doubts; but they are vain and groundless; my name's assum'd like thine.—For your embraces
form'd, and yours alone, these have been widow'd arms e'er since you lest me.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: My faithful wife! Come then again to mine, and dwell for ever there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Alas, my love, this meeting's like a vision. You seem as one new risen from the dead.—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: 'Tis the re-union of departed souls, favour'd by heav'n to meet again above, with joy unut∣terable.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Oh! let us, then, thank heav'n for such a meeting.—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: I cannot thank it better than I do. Heav'n knows the heart; and, from the fulness of my pre∣sent joy, sees mine o'erflow with gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Narcissa, come, and take a father's blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Is this my daughter too!

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Oh! my father.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: I will, but need not, bless thee. Heaven hath been so much kinder to thee than thy father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Welcome, my Frederic, to a mother's arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Do you, then, give your daughter to my wishes? Thus let me thank you for the precious gift. — [Kneeling, and kissing Mrs. Midmay's hand; then rising and turning to Narcissa.]—But will Narcissa ratify the grant?

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Indeed, brother— I know not what to say.—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Brother! Narcissa!

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Whence this mistake?— [to Mrs. Mildmay.] We have alas! no son: our Frederic died, poor boy, long since, in India.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild
SP.P: Then have my hopes and fears alike been fruitless.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.STAGE: [Aside, in a tone of joy and surprize.]
SP.P: —Again I feel my swelling heart replete.—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: How! what!

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: And you are not my brother then at last?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Your brother, Narcissa! No; dear as I might love a sister, I would not be your brother for the world. I see through the whole of your strange behaviour now.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: —This young gentle∣man, my dear, is son to a distant relation lately dead: to whose fortune he is heir, and to whose last will I am executor.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Hoity toity! here's a tangled skain un∣ravell'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: —And general Melmoth is Nar∣cissa's father!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter lord Courtly, introduc'd by servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Lord Courtly, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Ladies and gentlemen your servant. Hap∣pily assembled, I hope.—[turning to Young Melmoth.]— I presume, Mr. Melmoth is, by this time, convinc'd of the impropriety of the angry billet he sent me this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: The mistake we both lay under, my lord, at once justifies your behaviour and my resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Fortunately for me, however, that mistake drew a promise from the amiable Narcissa; which, I flatter myself, she is too generous to forget.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: It is true, my lord, I did promise to give you my hand, if Mr. Melmoth could not accept it: and, if you had come some few minutes ago, I should have been terribly puzzl'd what to say to you. But I can now keep my word, without your reaping any advantage from my promise.—

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Madam! Mrs. Mildmay, what have I to hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: Indeed, my lord, my present perplex∣ity of joy and surprize, makes me as incapable of ex∣pressing my obligations, as the event puts it out of my power to requite them. Narcissa is not Mr. Mel∣moth's sister; but, instead of a brother, she hath found a father, and I a husband; to whose guidance and protection we now are subject.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: With your leave then, madam, Mr. Mel∣moth shall be yet your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Then have I found, instead of lost, a father.
SP.STAGE: [Bowing to general Melmoth, who advances to embrace him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mild.
SP.P: As to the preference I once gave your lordship—

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: It lays me under an obligation, madam, that, in the present circumstances, makes all apology needless.

SP.SPEAKER: Narc.
SP.P: Generously said; is not it, Mr. Melmoth? —Indeed, my lord, I wish you a better wife than I should have made you.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: And I you, madam, all happiness, with a husband that deserves you.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Mel.
SP.P: I shall endeavour to merit the compliment, my lord.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter alderman Lombard, colonel Camply and Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: Your servant, gentlemen and ladies. You seem to be mighty well pleas'd here: my daughter Sophy and the colonel have let me a little into some∣thing—

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Oh, Camply! oh, my friend, behold my injur'd, much-wrong'd wife and daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Camp.
SP.P: Is it possible!

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: How, how! the widow Mildmay general Melmoth's wife!

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: I see you're fill'd with wonder! I could indeed, relate a tale most wonderful, but that excess of joy prevents its utterance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: Well then, we'll wait, general, 'till you are a little more sorrowful.—In the mean time, I must in∣form you, that I have settled matters with your friend Camply.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: I am glad of it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lomb.
SP.P: Ay, ay, my daughter and the borough go together. There, take her, colonel; and make her just as good a husband as she proves a wife—for my own part, I shall defer my matrimonial project to another opportunity: and, I think, it would not be amiss if his lordship follows my example.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Sir, I hope I shall always have generosity of temper enough, to rejoice in the happiness of others, though not directly conducive to my own.

SP.SPEAKER: G. Mel.
SP.P: Such a disposition, my lord, cannot go long unrewarded. Your lordship will do me honour in permitting me to cultivate a farther acquaintance with it. But, from the events of to-day, we may see how ineffectual are all attempts to separate those whom love hath united, and heaven preserv'd for each other.

SP.L: WHene'er physicians wrangle with each other,
And college-dons shut out each licens'd brother,
Should they throw squibs, made up of Latin scraps,
And come to pulling wigs, as women caps,
The sick grow well, —Death will not lay about him;
He has more honour than to work without 'em.
Should you [to the pit] whose skill and wisdom we ac∣knowledge,
The fellows of this old dramatic college,
(No matter what the cause of disputation,)
Crowd hither ev'ry night for altercation;
The Bard, half dead before, enjoys the sport,
Gets strength each day, and is the better for't.
Warm'd with this subject, let your fancies play,
And me, by licence, make a Doctor, pray;
Suppose this gown, a suit of velvet, plain,
With a gold button, and this fan a cane;
My cap a formal tye, most wisely big,
O, no—I had forgot—a smart bag wig:
No physic-bushes now are seen in town;
For all the signs, you know, are taken down;
Call me licentiate, fellow, what you will,
I'll feel your pulses all, —and prove my skill.
The pulses of the boxes first I feel, —
And by their beating will their thoughts reveal; [She acts the doctor feeling a pulse.
Languid and low—Wildman's old fashion'd story
Was much too nervous, to be set before ye.
For twelve long years, a tender wife forsaking,
Worn out with wand'ring, and what's worse, with raking:
Then to return, —He was not worth the taking.
As for the pulses of my friends above—
They thump for joy—when spouses kiss and love.—
Bless their young hearts, —what means this palpitation!
Each miss's blood is now in agitation!
Each quick pulsation for Narcissa beats;
When she went off—they scarce could keep their seats.
When Lombard talk'd of bribes, —how felt you that? [To the pit
Some pulses in this house went pat, pat, pat.
If this our night's prescription you have taken,
Without wry faces, or your heads much shaken;
If you perceive some character, some wit,
With plot and humour—quantum sufficit;
Mix'd up with sal-volatile of satire;
Let it—quotidie nocte repetatur.—
'Tis by our nostrums you are kept alive:
Pursue the regimen of doctor CLIVE.
